comments.commentBody: The truth is that we spend much of our healthcare dollar supporting very rich insurance and pharmaceutical  companies, period.  We need to go to a single payer system where our good MDs, nurses and other providers can do the work they were trained to do.  We need to provide our medical research scientists with the funding they need to advance medicine through research.  There is enough funding available, the issue is some very wealthy executives and their stockholders take off with these funds leaving the system, the providers and patients scrambling for crumbs.
I think you mean, no one to emulate.
This story may have been written beautifully, but this guy is a bum and a murderer, no one to emanate.

You're not "expected" to do anything - how you react is up to you. But it would be nice if you saw the story as excellent journalism without peering through the lens of race. The preponderance of major level sports writing weighs heavily black - simply because the majority of athletes in the largest sports stages are black. Likewise, many of them have compelling stories (equaling this one). Many of them are written about in fascinating detail, with empathy and sometimes sympathy or pathos.
I would be far less appreciative, much less exposed, to great writing if I only read based on the tally of black versus white, female versus male, protagonists.
Really? That's what you got out of this piece?  I could quote you 100 articles that make your point exactly.

Actually whites are killed by cops at a rate twice that of blacks, but somehow the overall police over-reaction only seems to matter if the person killed is black.

From the Chicago Tribune: "In 2015, The Washington Post launched a real-time database to track fatal police shootings, and the project continues this year. As of Sunday, 1,502 people have been shot and killed by on-duty police officers since Jan. 1, 2015. Of them, 732 were white, and 381 were black (and 382 were of another or unknown race)."

This piece is an exceptional example of white male+sports privilege. I doubt any person of color with a similar background would get such a sympathetic/complex human being write-up. Am I expected to feel some sympathy here for a man who fed his family by killing people simply because he could hit a baseball?

Obviously, professionalism takes on many forms. It seems like we can't keep from admiring the professional, even when his job is something heinous.

Lerner could have used some help early, maybe to untangle his feelings that he (apparently) kept to himself right up to the end of his life. The story also shows that it's not enough to have talent, rains and desire.

Great writing.
Even Junior Soprano respected the Atwells Avenue Boys from Providence.
It's amazing that we have progressed so little from the sad days of Rodney King. The taping of a police crime seems to have mattered little. Justice remains elusive.

To say that police like the thin blue line is to ignore that they routinely interact with an increasingly hostile public that projects their emotions instead of getting to know their officers.  From the precinct community council I attended, the African-Americans appreciated our officers most.

The farce continues. Perhaps they will decide to throw this one policeman under the bus to garner some millennial black votes for Hillary Clinton. Or perhaps just the appearance of justice finally being served will suffice.

One thing is clear: without nationwide reform of the way police are selected, trained, armed, and overseen things will only continue to get worse. The folks in the thin blue line like to think that it is them versus the rest of us, and it is becoming a self-fulfilling prophesy.
There are drug dealers who sell on street corners who don't meet the same fate....
"Losing" is still lost. All roads, even the weather, lead back to Hillary Clinton.  He's going to have a long four years of hate.
Michelle, you do realize that what was caught on camera was evidence correct?

I don't see Wall Street people being treated this way, or fellow police officers, or anyone else from the Political/Economic Elite.

Almost always only those that aren't a white male or white female.

With all the stats about the bad encounters between minorities and the police, in order to get Police Accountability, people that do stuff like what happened to Mr. Garner, or the people that have died recently, there has to be everyone treated the same under the color of law.

Otherwise, we will have more tension between the citizens and police, and potentially anarchy.

Two years and no end in sight to this case, utterly disgraceful and unacceptable. There was no justice, and no reason to use that kind of force to subdue Mr. Garner who wasn't trying to flee. It was a homicide and that officer is guilty of a capital crime.  When is this government going to show the political will and enforce the laws of this country to all it's citizens. This officer has a record of using excessive force, these thugs in blue uniforms should be locked up like any other criminal.
These beautiful and expansive photographs and 'motion pictures' make such a visual impact, the Times truly is the best in story telling.

Judy,
In forty years of medical practice, if I had a buck for every time I have seen this happen, I could pay current Med school tuition. Belief and disbelief both pale before reality.
What you see, pouncing, is not the norm but what is shown by the media.  Also. our police are faced with armed criminals, and many do resist arrest.
Police brutality is common in many places, not just the US. It happens in Australia, too. We need to make serious changes here, and a quick Google search shows that you in Australia need to as well.

The population of Australia is around 23 million, USA 318 million and your country does not have the problems within the inner cities that we do.  It's easy to sit across the sea and criticize, however I recall your government isn't exactly kind to the indigenous population.  I have friends in Europe who also criticized our law enforcement.  They are conveniently silent now that they are dealing with their own crime wave.

As an Australian i find your police practices appalling. Police in my country carry guns but not all of them. Our police are male and female. Our police are - physically - far smaller than your police, who appear mostly to be big beefy guys on steroids. Yet when our police arrest people they usually do so with minimal physical contact and, when it does come to it, one or two of our police can usually arrest someone without too much of a problem.

But the worst thing is the way the police in your country appear to pounce on people and take them down. That is not done as police practice anywhere else in the civilised world. It is extraordinary and it is a total breach of what would be ordinary police procedure anywhere else in the western world. It doesn't need to be done in the USA.

I keep hearing that the USA is "exceptional". Well, in many ways its just exceptionally stupid.
Last I saw selling loose cigarettes is not a capital offense.  Nobody deserves to be killed for doing so, no matter how often.  You are blaming the victim.
Thank you for that insightful comment, James Earl Ray

You are so wrong on the law it is not even funny. You don't even get the issues. No reasonable person disputes that force was legal against Mr. Garner who was resisting arrest. Nor do reasonable people dispute that the police were right to make an arrest. The police don't make the law, but they have to enforce it. The only issue is if too much force was used.
Black cops were involved in the arrest and the supervising cop was black too. No racism here - unless you intend to see every police-black interaction as racist.

It can't happen soon enough, every single person involved in the police department and the EMTs who did nothing whatsoever should be indicted, tried, convicted and jailed for murder conspiracy and failure to do their duty as public servants.

Of all the cases wherein white police officers use deadly force against a black person, the Eric Garner case stands out:  The "crime" he was accused of is clearly innocuous.  The use of force against him is clearly unwarranted,  The police assault against him, and his demise is documented.  The conservative politics that dominate Staten Island and infest the elements of its justice system clearly led to the non-indictment in this case.  It is the most clear-cut case of police violence resulting in the most clear-cut miscarriage of justice in the recent spate of similar cases.  This is the one case that calls out for judicial intervention.  I hope it comes soon.

GIven the state of things in NY State it seems to be good practice to have investigations and prosecutions relating to NYS criminal justice personnel handled by out-of-state agents and attorneys just as investigations of criminality in State government there need to be handled by US Attorneys. One need only look, for example, at the sickeningly cosy relationships between former Brooklyn DAs Hynes and Thompson and the ultra-Orthodox communities to realize that no serious prosecution of fraud or child sexual abuse either did or, while Thompson was living. was ever likely to have taken place. New York FBI invesigating NYPD? Laughable.
It's their culture. Remember Serpico!

LRP -- Eric Garner was marginally mentally ill, and had pretty serious health problems. Just being 400 lbs is a health problem. He was one of society's marginal, struggling, people.

Yes, he had a history of selling untaxed cigarettes ... but we don't sentence people to die for that, not even if they have done it repeatedly.

Just for contrast to a recent case -- Donald Blankenship, multimillionaire owner and operator of coal mines, was sentenced to 1 year in jail for blatantly ignoring (and countermanding) the safety requirements in a mine of his, resulting in the death of 29 miners.

And while serving his sentence, he has published a 69-page manifesto about how he is a "political prisoner."

I sure cannot find it in my heart to kill a poor black mentally-ill guy selling loose cigarettes, and it really discourages me that you can.

@MoreRadoshes

The line got crossed at:
Application of the Choke Hold -which the NYPD apparently banned...
and non response to I cant breath -
you don't as a police officer get to "choke him out" to force him to comply.

Yes he was resisting arrest
No you don't get to kill him for it...

A Trial Jury can decide the facts...
Sam, thank you for reminding us the Staten Island prosecutor was subsequently elected to Congress, just in case anyone had any doubt about the culpability of the citizenry.
The family got millions from the city of NY.
"The prosecutor who engineered the non-indictment was afterwards promoted to congressman. " Nope - was elected by approving voting citizens.

The prosecutor who engineered the non-indictment was afterwards promoted to congressman.

Imagine how the family of Mr. Garner, and the rest of the world indeed, perceive that? Especially while Justice Department dithers over whether to even bring charges.

Officer Panteleone was not only preening for the camera, knowing he was being videotaped, but his fellow officers went ahead and aggressively harassed the family of the kid who recorded the video.

What's the life of an artist innocent black man worth in America?
Right on,Brian J !

People outside of Canada don't get what we here understand; that we're prepared to make the compromises that are inherent with our systems, particularly health care.
I get that it sounds terrible that I can't see my designated health care provider that day, or the next for something unless it's acute, unusual, and causing immediate distress. In that case, if I can't get into my provider's clinic (because her time is fully committed), they'll recommend that I go to "emerg". There, I'll be triaged, and ultimately be examined and treated in accordance with my issue as compared to the others present. Sometimes I've been ushered straight in, sometimes I've had to wait for several hours. In each case however, if further examination - medical imaging in its variety of forms, medication or splinting, stitches, blood work - is required, I'm slotted into the next available space (never more than a couple of hours) and treated accordingly. Whatever is required is logged into "the system" and any health care provider who subsequently looks into what's transpired with me can see what was done, what the results of test etc were, and how it was left. It's up to me if I choose to fulfill or take the meds (if) recommended and follow-up further if required. But I've never seen a bill for what I've described, whether in the office, or "emerg". Nor has my wife for the birth of our kids (one via Caesarian) or any other procedure that was needed.
It's not perfect, but I can make it work.

It's "safe" to stick with the legal charge?

I'm outraged. Evil and exploitation should not be dressed up.

Thanks Liz Spayd for your headline, which is exactly right.

(Not that words fix the problem, but "safe" is needed for potential victims, not to exonerate a namby-pamby press afraid of its own shadow.)
